review_title: Employer with a mission and a conscience
pros: The company is a great place to work, with some leaders who prioritize honesty and transparency and genuinely care about their employees' well-being. There are ample opportunities for advancement, provided you have the patience and can demonstrate your value.
cons: Some leaders lack transparency, and unfortunately, the organization as a whole, along with certain departments, has failed to share its direction with team members. There is a prevalent sense of an "old boy network" among executives who have been with the company for decades, resulting in a disconnect from the realities within departments. Additionally, they tend to prioritize cost-cutting measures, leading to comparatively lower raises and compensation when compared to other local systems.

cons:

Receptionists rarely did their job, leaving the work to be done by the MA's.

Low pay.
High cost insurance.

job_title: Psychiatric Technician II in Tulsa, OK
pros: Fantastic benefits including dental, vision, medical, life, and other options. You choose your own hours, but there is a minimum you must meet weekly. PTO accrues pretty quickly.

pros: Hard to think of many. They have nice flowers.
cons:
This place is the absolute worst culture I’ve ever been in. Most of the folks here have never worked anywhere else, are highly unqualified for what they are doing and there is obvious nepotism lurking at every leadership position. They pay incredibly low wages. It’s actually amazing they’re able to recruit and retain anyone.

Everything requires a paper process. Everything. You can’t refill your water bottle without a form. This place is so paper heavy, the only reason to actually have a computer is to answer your emails (they have ancient versions of Microsoft office too). 

 Directors and below have to clock in and out because “they found a director taking advantage of being salaried.” Rather than fixing that issue directly with that individual, they made a blanketed change for everyone. I wonder if anyone ever thought about evaluating performance outside of the hours you work, let alone putting more than 5 minutes into someone’s annual evaluation? Of course, they don’t pay you overtime but you have to work 42.5 hours per week. Directors also have to wear the full suit and tie - talk about dated culture! If you don’t wear a tie, you’re tracked down and asked to put one on. 

There is zero focus on the culture let alone asking anyone how they are doing /liking their job at any given time. No opinions are ever asked and if they were, they wouldn’t matter. Leadership makes decisions in a vacuum behind closed doors without anyone’s input and that’s just the way it is. Deal with it. 

Leadership doesn’t play by the same rules as others have to. They park where they want (in delivery only or patient parking). Sometimes they choose not to wear a tie or jacket (but we have to), and of course they’re leaving at 3:00 on Fridays while us peons sit there twiddling our thumbs until 4:30 rolls around. 

Everyone has so much stock in this new CEO but the culture is so deeply engrained in the people that work here that it’ll likely take a decade to change anything.

They’ll hang their hat in their great benefits but what they won’t tell you in the interview is you’ll have to wait at least a year (sometimes 18 months) for the retirement match to kick in and to be fully vested you’ll have to sit in this hell for 6 years! 

I say again, this is the absolute worst culture I’ve ever encountered.

review_title: Good co-workers, yearly bonuses, Low pay, heavy/unsafe staffing assignments.

pros: They are very competitive with their pay. Some friendly staff..

If you work in an out location you will never see your bosses and it is very hard to get into communication with them when you have an issue.

cons: At Muskogee, when Saint Francis took over the hospital it didn’t remove some employees in their positions and some are carrying over toxicity from being there under different work ethics and principles. Saint Francis has amazing ideals and a structure dynamic that works but not when they do not see the toxic culture still there.

review_title: Extremely poor Director with no leadership skills
pros: A somewhat flexible work schedule
cons: Director has no leadership skills, has almost run this once flourishing agency into the ground. Can't even hire needed staff because she can't figure out how to meet productivity. She makes no independent decisions and lets 4 clincical managers (what home care agency with a census of barely over 400 has FOUR clinical managers) make emotional decisions-which she does as well. Loosing seasoned staff or removing positions that have been in place for the lifetime of the agency because she can't figure it out and her brother is a physician- yet she still has a position while 5-6 have been let go and a few more are about to be because she can't meet budget. When is corporate going to wake up and remove the REAL problem/s?

pros: Good benefits, safe working environment and manager cares about staff. Beautiful grounds and clean campus.
cons: Stuck in the good ole boy network; if you're not Catholic  or related to Jake Henry you won't advance beyond a director regardless of your education, experience, aptitude or capabilities . The Pink Attitude of upper management needs to go. I am proud to work at SFHS but executive leadership acts like our pink don't stink, and I'm here to say we have some stinky areas.

review_title: GREAT company that cares about people
pros: I work on the business side as opposed to the patient care side but I love that I still go to work every day and feel like what I do helps take care of our patients. It is not uncommon to see the Executive team walking the halls of the hospitals and taking time to stop and talk to the employees. I think that is one of the most unique and best aspects about Saint Francis- we are the only hospital left in town where decisions are made locally as opposed to a corporate office out of state. We may be the biggest company in town but there are still events taking place throughout the year to appreciate the employees- hospital appreciation week, all-employee party, Thanksgiving gift cards, etc. I love coming to work and feeling like I am making a difference in the lives of our patients, who are truly the top priority here.
cons: They do run the business lean, which is a pro and a con. It keeps us very financially stable but can require working extra hard to compensate for a smaller staffing ratio

pros: This company has the right set of values and truly appreciates their employees. I feel like I am truly part of a working family, and I enjoy coming to work. I love the fact that my management values the importance of family too and is understanding when the need arises to take care of personal business.
cons: As an employee, we are unable to volunteer in another part of the hospital. I would love to be able to volunteer at the Children's Hospital, but it isn't allowed at this time. Sometimes it would be nice to have a longer lunch period, but I know it is short for a reason.

job_title: IT Tech Support in Tulsa, OK
pros: Co-Workers can be like family and I have formed some lasting friendships from that
cons:
Senior leadership in IT is horrible and consistently makes bad hires in management within the department causing low morale and lots of people seeking employment elsewhere. 
There was very little to no communication coming from senior IT leadership or direct managers and people are basically left to fend for themselves because they have no direction from their manager or leadership.
I had less than 10 emails from the VP in their tenure there and none of them were about direction of the department. 
If you weren't involved in Epic then you didn't matter AT ALL to senior leadership
The Executive leadership could care less about IT and their employees. Their focus was on landscaping and painting the walls to make the place look like a hotel.

pros: This is one of the most satisfying jobs I have ever had. It has provided challenges and rewards unlike any other. There is a balance between work, community and family that allowed for a sense of accomplishment and truly makes me feel as if I am making a difference. The culture and values of the company make me more socially aware and active. My coworkers and higher ups are all very helpful and nice people too! I hope I'm here til I retire!!
cons: I am ECB, would love to be full time and able to get more benefits. But there are pros to being ECB too...

pros: This is a large hospital so a person is exposed to a lot of different situations & areas so you can get a better idea of where they want their career to go.
cons: The large size of the hospital has the downside of employees being lost in the crowd so advancement can be a challenge. I took an entry level job as a patient transporter to get my foot in the door. 3 months after taking the job I graduated with my bachelors degree from a nearby college. After over 1 1/2 years of trying to move into the business office, I eventually moved on to a different hospital.

review_title: Premier Health System in Northeastern Oklahoma
job_title: Human Resources Representative in Tulsa, OK
pros: I appreciate the opportunity to work in a facility within the health system that offers professional and lifestyle incentives within a collaborative working environment.  I would recommend Saint Francis Health System wholeheartedly!  We have an excellent reputation in the community and serve a wide patient population.  Come join us!
cons: Normally, I would say, working in a large facility is for those who enjoy only that large working culture, however Saint Francis Health System consists of both large and smaller facility environments, plus Clinics.

review_title: Employees to follow mission statement but not the employer.
pros: 401k benefit generous.
cons: Double standards and follow through with promises. Employees not treated well, especially ones who have been there many years.

review_title: It's ok, stressful at times, but this is healthcare we're talking about.
pros: Great benefits and pay is decent for no previous experience. Then add in the shift and weekend differentials.
cons: New employee orientation on the floor I was assigned really had flaws. Adore my trainer as a person and co worker, however at the end of orientation I found myself not as prepared as I would have liked to be. Mostly had to figure out all the small details on my own. Charting program for example. I was shown 1 time by my trainer what charting looks like. And Bedside shift reports are done on paper for each room to be discussed at the end of each shift and filled out with each new patient... I had no clue where to find the information required for this damn paper. Finally, a nurse explained where to find certain information on a patient and helped me fill out this thing, while my training tech was off having coffee with a pastor visiting the floor...or was it her favorite patients room she was hiding in for over an hour despite several calls for help and 30 minutes later showing up to help me with a patient after having to figure it out myself to find out the "important" conversation about India. Definitly more important than my patients health. End of shift or bedside reports are a hit and miss.. Either the tech coming off their shift actually cared about their patient and job or doesn't.. Either they actually know what's going on or don't and really dont care too. Some will go room to room while other could care less. Every patient is a problem to them unless drugged up and knocked out or asleep on their own will. Lack of hygiene care is something I've witnessed as well along with not placing call light or phone within reach..  I had to physically crawl under and behind a bed to untangle the call button and phone from the bed itself and unwrap it from the beds wheels. My patient wasn't even aware he had a phone and had been wondering how to ask for help... Did I mention he was completely restricted to bed rest ONLY which was not on our precious reports in fact it was completely inaccurate nor easily found in chart and lead to my patient falling and it fell to my shoulders and complete lack of knowledge.

review_title: IS Department is a Great Organization
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Tulsa, OK
pros: Very flexible.  Great culture.  People are fun to be around and work with.  Moving in the right direction as far as technology.
cons: Only allowed to take whole days for vacation.  No 1/2 days.  Not allowed to work from home on inclement weather days.  Progress has been made but still need to work on upgrading the organizational technology.

pros:
Excellent facilities & equiptment.
Wonderful, team-oriented co-workers.
Free vaccinations as needed.
Health Insurance & 401K available (caveat emptor).
Provides free, on-going, in-house training for job-related knowledge & skills.
Well-organized hierarchy & chain of command.
cons:
The hospital itself is a vast labyrinth, easy to get lost in... the fleshy-pink exterior is an eyesore. 

Like any large hospital, its bureacracy is at least as vast as its physical buildings... and equally impenetrable if you're not a doctor, RN, or administrator. The red tape is thick with this one...

Treats entry-level & lower-on-the-totem-pole employees as expendable, no matter how long they work there or how good they are at their jobs... e.g. CNA's, Techs, PCT's etc. Crappy pay +  crappy job + the 'expendable' attitude mentioned above = high burnout & turnover rates for these sorts of positions.

Physical demands of the job ended up being much greater than advertised in job descriptions, at least on the unit I worked on... this should have been made clearer upfront.

Health Insurance policies available not worth it.

review_title: Don't take a sign on bonus!!! Leave your options open!!!
pros: The food in the cafeteria is great and the gift shop always has cute clothes. Some of the seasoned nurses are very helpful.
cons: No holiday pay and not being told there is no holiday pay until after a contract is signed, $1000.00 deductible no matter which insurance plan you choose, 6 to 7 patients per day due to being understaffed for many reasons, and having the full amount of sign up bonuses paid up front so if you leave you have to pay back $8000.00. $8000.00 really amounts to $4000.00 after taxes.

job_title: Phlebotomist II in Broken Arrow, OK
pros: They were usually accommodating for time off. Overall, the staff as a whole worked well together. The company party is always fun, and the food at the party is pretty good.
cons: The management could care less about the employees well being. Call-ins were frequent, and we often worked short staffed. The pay is horrible; and myself and co-workers were stuck on the elevators on multiple occasions.

pros: This organization really cares about it's employees! They strive to arrange their finances so that SFH stays debt free; insuring that it's employees don't have to be cut to save costs. They also have an on-site daycare program, as well as a Health Club for employees. Saint Francis is a great place to work and they take their Mission, Vision, and Values very seriously and strive to abide by them.
cons: The benefits could be a little better, however, they aren't too bad at all.

review_title: My experience overall has been positive as the company focuses on providing excellent care to its patients.
pros: Patient focused care, financially sound, has delivered bonuses to employees every year I've been employed (since 2006)
cons: Tends to be rigid and set in ways with certain policies, could do more to recognize employees contributions, medical benefits are not great

review_title: Not the best but not the worst.
pros: Coworkers, education opportunities, benefits, facilities are great, cafeteria, pay, always have the tools needed, doctors and nurses are generally polite and appreciate techs
cons: Patient to tech ratio was borderline insane for the amount of responsibilities (certain floors), management didn't care why something wasn't completed (not answering a call light because of an emergency with another patient was grounds for a write up), no set breaks/expected to work through all breaks. Constant calls to cover extra shifts past your scheduled hours.

review_title: Never balance of staff. High turnover
pros: Always hours available and never sent home on a scheduled day. Competitive pay
cons: Never enough staff, overwhelming with a heavy loads Staff leaving in droves. No lunch breaks

pros: The environment is incredible to work in. It has been my favorite hospital so far! The managers genuinely care about their staff and go the extra mile to support and protect them.
cons: Like most hospitals we would be understaffed quite a bit and as a Nurse Tech your day would get really hectic.

pros:
Working ECB allowed me to attend college classes while working
Christmas bonus & year 3-5% raises
Double holiday pay (for ECB) only
Overtime available
cons:
Schedule varies unless you're full-time employee
Management sucks
Lazy staff
High school gossip atmosphere 
Same job day after day
Management is two-faced
Can't trust your own boss
Room for little growth and even after you take on more work tasks you probably wont receive the promotion.

review_title: Great people meh benifits and poor response to covid
pros: good people great environment facilities are nice compensation is fair
cons: the sick leave is bad it's not 4/year its a year after you use one you get it back so it turns into really 4 per 2 years, staff rations not great but manageable, did not handle covid well one n95 ever so you may end up using it for a month.

review_title: Dont work here unless ya like to get back stabbed.
job_title: Engineering and Operations in Tulsa, OK
pros: It's a job that goes no where.
cons: Management don't care for anyone but how good you can make them look. Underpayed for the square footage one person has to cover and be responsible for. Management always takes the nurses word over yours. Cafeteria is way overpriced along with the medical insurance, which St.Francis and St. John's owns. To them your just a warm body to do the jobs they don't want to do or can do.

pros: Mom-Pop shop/hospital that is largest hospital in Tulsa, so far.
cons: Next to no management communication and treatment of employees. The old ways of doing things is the best way of doing things, so Hospital is very resistant to change. Top leadership make decisions based on their own bonus', which they govern themselves, since no real Executive pay committee.

pros: The health insurance was better than I expected.
cons: Very cold and clicky culture.  Management is not approachable.  Salary is the worst, about 12% below average.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Tulsa, OK
pros: Great doctors and coworkers. Everyone is caring and know they're there to make a difference. Worked there for 8 years and would've stayed, but they don't hire LPN's.
cons: Low pay compared to other hospitals in the area. Bonuses were a joke, but better than nothing. Seems like they invest a lot into building bigger buildings, but don't invest in their workers.

pros: Really hard to name any. Some great employees.
cons: Old school mind set. Not open to listening to employee opinions or concerns. Say they run lean but in truth just cheap and expect employers to work crazy hours to get work done. No work life balance. Only leadership gets bonuses. Well let's be fair employees get a $400 bonus. What a joke.

review_title: Not a bad place to work.
pros: Faith based employer, good 401K program, decent pay, health insurance is ok, beautiful campus, lots of jobs available, some really good people
cons: Pay scale seems very jumbled, lack of advancement opportunities, no merit based pay increases, very much "good ole boy" type operating structure

pros: Good People, Everyone is nice to each other.
cons: Everything is old school, very paper heavy, outdated systems, all the work is very manual.  I feel like I've stepped back in time to the 19th century.

review_title: Not a job to do unless you want to be a nurse.
pros: Good way to gain healthcare experiance.
cons: The company will put you at the bottom of a long ladder and constantly remind you that you are there and if you don't like it they don't care.

job_title: Licensed Clinical Therapist in Tulsa, OK
pros: Excellent co-workers and management, very high skill level among employees, top-notch research and treatment center, rewarding work
cons: Very challenging work, boundaries change frequently, based on the patient and situation (also can be a strength), some cliques among certain workers - can be difficult to manage.  Less than ideal training - much time learning on the job.

pros: Company paid continuing education, PTO, ESL, company contributes to 401k
cons: Management is really lacking and communication is a disaster, at least in my department. Politics are some of the worst I've seen. Have to request a day off 2 months in advance.

review_title: Mostly positive and a pleasant environment to work.
pros:
Covered parking
Yearly bonus
Help with paying for the cost of uniforms. 
Benefit plan. 
Employee assistance for emergencies is available.
cons:
Health insurance is expensive 
Office politics can get frustrating 
Overtime is not readily available. 
Annual pay raise, but very small. Pay raise is not based on performance or merit but across the board.

pros:
Patient focused, good physicians on staff who truly care about the patient well being, teamwork.
I was encouraged to excel and learn to better myself.  Orientation was thorough.
cons: Charting is lengthy with Ulticare, working short staffed too frequently and unit secretary does not work after 7.

pros: It was a good work environment. I had good benefits and pay. I also love helping people and learning new things
cons: It was a lot of mental work and was hard not to build relationships with the patients and take home with you the bad part of the job.

pros: Great benefits and good pay. A lot of opportunities for advancement also, overall a good place to work, met a lot of lifelong friends too.
cons: Some of the people working there are very lazy and is very good at complaining. There is no incentive for good employees

job_title: Health Information Management in Tulsa, OK
pros: They care about their employees.  I love the faith based atmosphere.
cons: Parking is awful.  Only a 3% raise per year, although we do usually get a bonus.  Health insurance is a bit high for working at a healthcare organization.

cons: The last two years the department has been under staffed and the patient load is too high to adequately care for your patients to the standard they deserve.

review_title: Poorly run hospital and bad wages
pros: Nice group of employees. Hospital is very clean. They have a nice gift shop. Coffee is good.
cons: Poor management and salaries.. Walked into work. Badges were taken from us and we where let go.. people sit by title in the lunch room. Interns work long and hard hours. Short staffed.

review_title: I liked the close relationships in my department.

cons: Sometimes a little too rigid with rules and policies; understandable but there are times for exceptions too.

cons: Personal development is frowned upon if it conflicts with staffing needs. High turn over/difficulty retaining nursing with large influx of new nurses constitutes challenge to patient safety.

pros: They have great food in the cafeteria. Usually, there was plenty of overtime available if you wanted it. They offer free stuff to employees sometimes, like: free food, free lunch boxes, etc.
cons: Great company. My experience was only positive.

pros: Great people and all around good place to work, once you've got more tenure the pay scale is much more equal to larger cities.
cons: Pay is different on all levels, the entry level positions certainly lack on pay scale.

pros: One of the best organizations to be a part of in Tulsa. Benefits are fantastic.
cons: Strict budget in a lot of departments. Lots of departments are often short staffed because budget won't allow more help.
